citations.narrative:
The facility is not keeping a Record of Acquisition of Dogs and Cats on hand form (APHIS form 7005) for the dogs at the
facility. Failure to use APHIS form 7005 does not allow for proper traceability and management of regulated animals at a
facility.
Each dealer and exhibitor shall use the Record of Acquisition of Dogs and Cats on Hand (APHIS Form 7005) and Record
of Disposition of Dogs and Cats (APHIS Form 7006) to make, keep, and maintain the information required by paragraph
(a)(1) of this section. Provided, that if a dealer or exhibitor who uses a computerized recordkeeping system believes that
APHIS Form 7005 and APHIS Form 7006 are unsuitable for him or her to make, keep, and maintain the information
required by paragraph (a)(1) of this section, the dealer or exhibitor may request a variance from the requirement to use
APHIS Form 7005 and APHIS form 7006. Correct by ensuring all required information is fully and correctly documented
on an APHIS Form 7005 or by obtaining a variance. Correct by 23-OCTOBER-2023.

The facility is not meeting the record keeping requirements set forth by the AWA:
-The animal disposition records for unlicensed buyers do not contain the required information including the vehicle license
number and state, and the driver’s license number (or photographic identification card for nondrivers issued by the state).
-All of the animal disposition records for licensed buyers do not contain the required information including the USDA
license number or registration number of the person if her or she is licensed or registered under the act.
Failure to maintain complete and accurate records of acquisition, disposition, and record of animals on hand prevents
APHIS officials from disease tracking, animal movement, and determining compliance with the Animal Welfare Act.
Correct by ensuring that the facility maintains complete and accurate records of all animals on hand, all animal
acquisitions (including the total offspring born of any animal while in his possession or under his control) and animal
dispositions (including those which die, are euthanized, sold, transferred, or otherwise disposed of). These records must
include all information required by this section, must be maintained in an accurate and timely manner, and must be made
available for inspection by APHIS Officials.

The written Program of Veterinary Care (PVC) does not include requirements for the puppies. The PVC does not address
requirements for the puppies including a schedule for sampling and treatment for parasites and other pests (including
fleas, worms, coccidia, giardia, and heartworm) and a schedule for vaccinations. Failure to have a schedule for parasite
sampling and vaccinations does not ensure the puppies are adequately protected from diseases and parasites. The
written program of veterinary care for the puppies must address the requirements for adequate veterinary care and must
include vaccinations for contagious and/or deadly diseases of dogs (including rabies, parvovirus, and distemper) and
sampling and treatment of parasites and other pests (including fleas, worms, coccidia, giardia, and heartworm) in
accordance with a schedule approved by the attending veterinarian. Correct by having the Attending Veterinarian update
and approve the written program of veterinary care for the puppies with all the required information. Correct by 16-
November-2023.

Enclosures are not protecting animals from injury:
-An enclosure housing one adult female domestic cow and one calf has woven wire fencing that is in disarray with many
loose and bent areas with broken wires creating an excessive amount of sharp points.
-An enclosure housing 10 Domestic Goats has galvanized wire fencing with sharp points on the edges where two fence
panels meet. The sharp points are primarily at the meeting point of the panels on the raised bridge that is provided for the
goats.
Failure to maintain enclosure fencing in a manner that is not loose or contains sharp points can result in entrapment,
injury, and escape of the animals contained. Correct by ensuring that the facility is constructed of such material and of
such strength as appropriate for the animals involved. Additionally, the housing facilities shall be structurally sound and
shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals. This was corrected during
the inspection.

An enclosure housing two adult Emu has galvanized wire fencing material that has many sharp points. The sharp points
are primarily along the bottom of the back wall of the enclosure near the ground. Failure to ensure that no sharp points
are present in enclosures housing birds can result in injuries to the birds or can lead to possible entrapment of the neck or
legs of the birds. Correct by ensuring that all primary enclosures are kept in good repair and are free of sharp points or
edges that could injure birds. This was corrected during the inspection.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The licensee was unable to provide a written environmental enhancement plan for the avian species held at the facility. A
written plan is necessary to ensure that the overall health, well-being, and psychological needs of the birds are being
appropriately met. Failure to follow a species-appropriate environmental enhancement plan can lead to psychological
distress and abnormal behaviors in birds housed at the facility. Facilities that house avian species must develop,
document, and follow a species-appropriate plan for environment enhancement adequate to promote the psychological
well-being of birds. The plan must be in accordance with the currently accepted professional standards as cited in
appropriate professional journals or reference guides, and be approved by the attending veterinarian. The plan must
address social grouping, environmental enrichment, special considerations, restraint devices, and exemptions. The
environmental enhancement plan must be made available to APHIS officials upon request. Correct by 16-November-
2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the Licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
Mark Sanderbeck, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n

narrative:
2.75(a)(2) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The facility is not keeping a Record of Acquisition of Dogs and Cats on hand form (APHIS form 7005) for the dogs at the 
facility. Failure to use APHIS form 7005 does not allow for proper traceability and management of regulated animals at a 
facility.  
 
Each dealer and exhibitor shall use the Record of Acquisition of Dogs and Cats on Hand (APHIS Form 7005) and Record 
of Disposition of Dogs and Cats (APHIS Form 7006) to make, keep, and maintain the information required by paragraph 
(a)(1) of this section. Provided, that if a dealer or exhibitor who uses a computerized recordkeeping system believes that 
APHIS Form 7005 and APHIS Form 7006 are unsuitable for him or her to make, keep, and maintain the information 
required by paragraph (a)(1) of this section, the dealer or exhibitor may request a variance from the requirement to use 
APHIS Form 7005 and APHIS form 7006. Correct by ensuring all required information is fully and correctly documented 
on an APHIS Form 7005 or by obtaining a variance. Correct by 23-OCTOBER-2023. 
2.75(b)(1)  Repeat
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The facility is not meeting the record keeping requirements set forth by the AWA: 
 
-The animal disposition records for unlicensed buyers do not contain the required information including the vehicle license 
number and state, and the driver’s license number (or photographic identification card for nondrivers issued by the state). 
 
-All of the animal disposition records for licensed buyers do not contain the required information including the USDA 
license number or registration number of the person if her or she is licensed or registered under the act. 
 
Failure to maintain complete and accurate records of acquisition, disposition, and record of animals on hand prevents 
APHIS officials from disease tracking, animal movement, and determining compliance with the Animal Welfare Act. 
Correct by ensuring that the facility maintains complete and accurate records of all animals on hand, all animal 
acquisitions (including the total offspring born of any animal while in his possession or under his control) and animal 
dispositions (including those which die, are euthanized, sold, transferred, or otherwise disposed of). These records must

include all information required by this section, must be maintained in an accurate and timely manner, and must be made 
available for inspection by APHIS Officials. 
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The written Program of Veterinary Care (PVC) does not include requirements for the puppies. The PVC does not address 
requirements for the puppies including a schedule for sampling and treatment for parasites and other pests (including 
fleas, worms, coccidia, giardia, and heartworm) and a schedule for vaccinations. Failure to have a schedule for parasite 
sampling and vaccinations does not ensure the puppies are adequately protected from diseases and parasites. The 
written program of veterinary care for the puppies must address the requirements for adequate veterinary care and must 
include vaccinations for contagious and/or deadly diseases of dogs (including rabies, parvovirus, and distemper) and 
sampling and treatment of parasites and other pests (including fleas, worms, coccidia, giardia, and heartworm) in 
accordance with a schedule approved by the attending veterinarian. Correct by having the Attending Veterinarian update 
and approve the written program of veterinary care for the puppies with all the required information. Correct by 16-
November-2023. 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
Enclosures are not protecting animals from injury: 
 
-An enclosure housing one adult female domestic cow and one calf has woven wire fencing that is in disarray with many 
loose and bent areas with broken wires creating an excessive amount of sharp points.  
 
-An enclosure housing 10 Domestic Goats has galvanized wire fencing with sharp points on the edges where two fence 
panels meet. The sharp points are primarily at the meeting point of the panels on the raised bridge that is provided for the 
goats.  
 
Failure to maintain enclosure fencing in a manner that is not loose or contains sharp points can result in entrapment, 
injury, and escape of the animals contained. Correct by ensuring that the facility is constructed of such material and of 
such strength as appropriate for the animals involved. Additionally, the housing facilities shall be structurally sound and 
shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals. This was corrected during 
the inspection. 
3.153(a)(1)(i) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
An enclosure housing two adult Emu has galvanized wire fencing material that has many sharp points. The sharp points 
are primarily along the bottom of the back wall of the enclosure near the ground. Failure to ensure that no sharp points 
are present in enclosures housing birds can result in injuries to the birds or can lead to possible entrapment of the neck or 
legs of the birds. Correct by ensuring that all primary enclosures are kept in good repair and are free of sharp points or 
edges that could injure birds. This was corrected during the inspection.

3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
The licensee was unable to provide a written environmental enhancement plan for the avian species held at the facility. A 
written plan is necessary to ensure that the overall health, well-being, and psychological needs of the birds are being 
appropriately met. Failure to follow a species-appropriate environmental enhancement plan can lead to psychological 
distress and abnormal behaviors in birds housed at the facility. Facilities that house avian species must develop, 
document, and follow a species-appropriate plan for environment enhancement adequate to promote the psychological 
well-being of birds. The plan must be in accordance with the currently accepted professional standards as cited in 
appropriate professional journals or reference guides, and be approved by the attending veterinarian. The plan must 
address social grouping, environmental enrichment, special considerations, restraint devices, and exemptions. The 
environmental enhancement plan must be made available to APHIS officials upon request. Correct by 16-November-
2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the Licensee. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Mark Sanderbeck, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n
